### Section: 1.1 Crystalline Lattice:

In the previous chapter, we discussed the concept of a unit cell and its importance in understanding the symmetry and structure of a crystal. In this section, we will delve deeper into the concept of a crystalline lattice, which is the underlying structure of a crystal.

#### 1.1a Definition of a Crystal Structure

A crystal structure is a description of the ordered arrangement of atoms, ions, or molecules in a crystalline material. This ordered structure occurs from the intrinsic nature of the constituent particles to form symmetric patterns that repeat along the principal directions of three-dimensional space in matter.

The smallest group of particles in the material that constitutes this repeating pattern is the unit cell of the structure. The unit cell completely reflects the symmetry and structure of the entire crystal, which is built up by repetitive translation of the unit cell along its principal axes. The translation vectors define the nodes of the Bravais lattice.

The lengths of the principal axes, or edges, of the unit cell and the angles between them are the lattice constants, also called "lattice parameters" or "cell parameters". The symmetry properties of the crystal are described by the concept of space groups. All possible symmetric arrangements of particles in three-dimensional space may be described by the 230 space groups.

The crystal structure and symmetry play a critical role in determining many physical properties, such as cleavage, electronic band structure, and optical transparency. In the next section, we will explore the concept of a crystalline lattice in more detail.

#### 1.1b Types of Crystalline Lattices

There are three main types of crystalline lattices: simple cubic, body-centered cubic, and face-centered cubic. These lattices are characterized by the arrangement of particles within the unit cell.

In a simple cubic lattice, the particles are located at the corners of the unit cell. This lattice is characterized by a high degree of symmetry and is commonly found in many crystalline materials.

In a body-centered cubic lattice, the particles are located at the corners of the unit cell, as well as at the center of the cell. This lattice is less symmetric than the simple cubic lattice, but it is still commonly found in many crystalline materials.

In a face-centered cubic lattice, the particles are located at the corners of the unit cell, as well as at the center of each face of the cell. This lattice is the most symmetric of the three and is commonly found in many metallic crystals.

The type of crystalline lattice present in a material can greatly influence its physical properties. For example, the simple cubic lattice is commonly found in diamond, which is known for its hardness and high melting point. On the other hand, the body-centered cubic lattice is commonly found in iron, which is known for its malleability and ductility.

#### 1.1c Bravais Lattice

The Bravais lattice is a concept in crystallography that describes the arrangement of lattice points in a crystal structure. It is named after the French mathematician and physicist Augustin-Louis Cauchy and the French mathematician and physicist Louis-Marie-Achille Briavais.

In three-dimensional space, there are 14 Bravais lattices. These are obtained by combining one of the seven lattice systems with one of the centering types. The centering types identify the locations of the lattice points in the unit cell as follows:

1. Primitive (P) - Each lattice point is in a unique location.
2. Body-centered cubic (I) - Each lattice point is surrounded by eight others in a cube.
3. Face-centered cubic (F) - Each lattice point is surrounded by four others on a face of a cube.
4. Body-centered tetragonal (I) - Each lattice point is surrounded by eight others in a tetragonal prism.
5. Face-centered tetragonal (F) - Each lattice point is surrounded by four others on a face of a tetragonal prism.
6. Body-centered hexagonal (I) - Each lattice point is surrounded by eight others in a hexagonal prism.
7. Face-centered hexagonal (F) - Each lattice point is surrounded by four others on a face of a hexagonal prism.
8. Body-centered orthorhombic (I) - Each lattice point is surrounded by eight others in an orthorhombic prism.
9. Face-centered orthorhombic (F) - Each lattice point is surrounded by four others on a face of an orthorhombic prism.
10. Base-centered cubic (C) - Each lattice point is surrounded by four others on a base of a cube.
11. Body-centered monoclinic (I) - Each lattice point is surrounded by eight others in a monoclinic prism.
12. Face-centered monoclinic (F) - Each lattice point is surrounded by four others on a face of a monoclinic prism.
13. Base-centered tetragonal (C) - Each lattice point is surrounded by four others on a base of a tetragonal prism.
14. Body-centered hexagonal (I) - Each lattice point is surrounded by eight others in a hexagonal prism.

Not all combinations of lattice systems and centering types are needed to describe all of the possible lattices, as it can be shown that several of these are in fact equivalent to each other. For example, the monoclinic I lattice can be described by a monoclinic C lattice by different choice of crystal axes. Similarly, all A- or B-centered lattices can be described either by a C- or P-centering. This reduces the number of combinations to 14 conventional Bravais lattices, shown in the table below.

### Introduction

In the realm of quantum physics, the Schrödinger equation holds a pivotal role. It is a fundamental equation that describes how the quantum state of a physical system changes over time. This chapter, "Schrödinger Equation," will delve into the intricacies of this equation, its implications, and its applications in the field of solid state physics.

The Schrödinger equation, named after the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger, is a wave equation that describes the wave-like behavior of particles. It is a cornerstone of quantum mechanics, providing a mathematical description of the physical world at the atomic and subatomic levels. The equation is used to calculate the probability of finding a particle at a certain point in space at a given time.

In the context of solid state physics, the Schrödinger equation is used to describe the behavior of electrons in a solid. It provides a mathematical framework for understanding the electronic properties of materials, including their energy levels, wave functions, and probability distributions. The equation is also instrumental in the study of quantum phenomena such as superconductivity and quantum computing.

This chapter will guide you through the mathematical formulation of the Schrödinger equation, its physical interpretation, and its applications in solid state physics. We will explore the equation in one, two, and three dimensions, and discuss its implications for the behavior of particles in a solid. We will also delve into the concept of wave functions and probability distributions, and how they are used to describe the state of a particle.

### Section: 1.2 Debye Waller Factor and Incommensurate Structures:

In the previous section, we discussed the concept of a crystalline lattice and its importance in understanding the structure of a crystal. In this section, we will explore the Debye Waller factor and its role in understanding the thermal vibrations of atoms within a crystal lattice.

#### 1.2a Debye-Waller Factor and Thermal Vibrations

The Debye Waller factor, named after the German physicist Peter Debye, is a dimensionless factor that describes the reduction in intensity of X-ray diffraction peaks in a crystal due to thermal vibrations. It is a measure of the disorder introduced by thermal motion in a crystal lattice.

The Debye Waller factor, denoted as $B$, is defined as the ratio of the observed intensity of a diffraction peak to the intensity that would be observed if there were no thermal vibrations. Mathematically, it can be expressed as:

$$
B = \frac{I_{obs}}{I_{theo}}
$$

where $I_{obs}$ is the observed intensity and $I_{theo}$ is the theoretical intensity.

The Debye Waller factor is a function of temperature and the Debye temperature, $\Theta_D$, which is a characteristic temperature for each crystal structure. The Debye temperature is defined as:

$$
\Theta_D = \left(\frac{12\pi^4R^3k_Bn}{V}\right)^{1/3}
$$

where $R$ is the atomic radius, $k_B$ is the Boltzmann constant, $n$ is the number of atoms per unit cell, and $V$ is the volume of the unit cell.

The Debye Waller factor increases with temperature, reaching a maximum at the Debye temperature. Above the Debye temperature, the factor decreases with temperature. This behavior is due to the increasing thermal vibrations in the crystal lattice, which cause the atoms to move further away from their equilibrium positions, reducing the intensity of the diffraction peaks.

The Debye Waller factor is a crucial concept in the study of thermal vibrations in crystals. It provides a quantitative measure of the disorder introduced by thermal motion in a crystal lattice, and it is directly related to the temperature and the Debye temperature of the crystal. Understanding the Debye Waller factor is essential for understanding the thermal properties of crystals and their response to temperature changes.

The concept of incommensurate structures is closely related to the concept of incommensurate modulation. Incommensurate modulation is a type of modulation that occurs in a crystal structure where the modulation vector is not commensurate with the lattice vector. This results in a complex crystal structure that cannot be described by a simple unit cell.

Incommensurate structures are often observed in materials with complex crystal structures, such as certain types of polymers and some types of metals. They are also observed in certain types of biological molecules, such as proteins and DNA.

## Chapter: Chapter 2: Fermi Energy and Fermi Surface

### Introduction

In the realm of solid-state physics, the concepts of Fermi energy and Fermi surface are fundamental to understanding the behavior of electrons in solids. This chapter, "Fermi Energy and Fermi Surface," will delve into these two crucial concepts, providing a comprehensive understanding of their significance and implications in the study of solids.

The Fermi energy, denoted as $E_F$, is a key parameter in the Fermi-Dirac statistics, which describe the probability distribution of fermions (particles with half-integer spin, such as electrons) in a system. It is defined as the energy at which the probability of occupation is 50% at absolute zero temperature. The Fermi energy plays a pivotal role in determining the electronic properties of a solid, including its electrical and thermal conductivity.

On the other hand, the Fermi surface is a concept that describes the energy-momentum relationship of electrons in a solid. It is a three-dimensional surface in the energy-momentum space, where the probability of finding an electron is maximum. The shape and size of the Fermi surface are influenced by the crystal structure and the band structure of the solid. Understanding the Fermi surface is crucial for predicting the electronic properties of a solid, especially its response to external perturbations such as electric and magnetic fields.

In this chapter, we will explore the mathematical formulations of the Fermi energy and Fermi surface, and discuss their physical interpretations. We will also examine the implications of these concepts in various types of solids, including metals, insulators, and semiconductors. By the end of this chapter, readers should have a solid understanding of these fundamental concepts and their role in the study of solids.




#### 1.2b Incommensurate Structures and Quasicrystals

In the previous section, we discussed the Debye Waller factor and its role in understanding the thermal vibrations of atoms within a crystal lattice. In this section, we will explore the concept of incommensurate structures and their relationship with quasicrystals.

##### Incommensurate Structures

An incommensurate structure is a type of crystal structure where the lattice vectors of two sublattices are not commensurate, meaning they cannot be expressed as a rational multiple of each other. This results in a periodic structure that is not translationally invariant, leading to a complex diffraction pattern.

The concept of incommensurate structures is closely related to the concept of quasiperiodicity. In fact, the first incommensurate structure was discovered in the 1960s by mathematicians studying aperiodic tilings, which are a type of quasiperiodic structure.

##### Quasicrystals

A quasicrystal is a type of incommensurate structure that exhibits quasiperiodicity. Quasiperiodicity is a property of a structure where it is ordered but not periodic. This means that the structure lacks translational symmetry, which is a fundamental property of periodic structures.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the 1980s was a major breakthrough in the field of crystallography. It challenged the classical crystallographic restriction theorem, which states that crystals can possess only two-, three-, four-, and six-fold rotational symmetries. The discovery of quasicrystals showed that there are structures that exhibit five-fold symmetry, among others.

The existence of quasicrystals was predicted in 1981 by a five-fold symmetry study of Alan Lindsay Mackay. This prediction was later confirmed by the crystallographic Fourier transform of a Penrose tiling, which showed the possibility of identifying quasiperiodic order in a material through diffraction.

In 2009, after a dedicated search, a mineralogical finding, icosahedrite, offered evidence for the existence of natural quasicrystals. This discovery marked a significant milestone in the study of quasicrystals and their properties.

##### Roughly, an ordering is non-periodic if it lacks translational symmetry, which means that a shifted copy will never match exactly with its original. The more precise mathematical definition is that there is never translational symmetry in more than "n" – 1 linearly independent directions, where "n" is the dimension of the space filled, e.g., the three-dimensional tiling displayed in a quasicrystal may have translational symmetry in two directions. Symmetrical diffraction patterns result from the existence of an indefinitely large number of elements with a regular spacing, a proper

#### 1.3a Definition of Point Group

In the previous section, we discussed the concept of incommensurate structures and their relationship with quasicrystals. In this section, we will explore the concept of point groups and their role in understanding the symmetries of crystals.

##### Point Groups

A point group is a mathematical group of symmetry operations that have a fixed point in common. In the context of crystallography, these operations are isometries, meaning they preserve the distance between any two points in a Euclidean space. The coordinate origin of the Euclidean space is conventionally taken to be a fixed point, and every point group in dimension "d" is then a subgroup of the orthogonal group O("d").

Each point group can be represented as sets of orthogonal matrices "M" that transform point "x" into point "y" according to "y" = "Mx". Each element of a point group is either a rotation (determinant of "M" = 1), or it is a reflection or improper rotation (determinant of "M" = −1).

##### Chiral and Achiral Point Groups

Point groups can be classified into "chiral" (or purely rotational) groups and "achiral" groups. The chiral groups are subgroups of the special orthogonal group SO("d"): they contain only orientation-preserving orthogonal transformations, i.e., those of determinant +1. The achiral groups contain also transformations of determinant −1. In an achiral group, the orientation-preserving transformations form a (chiral) subgroup of index 2.

Finite Coxeter groups or "reflection groups" are those point groups that are generated purely by a set of reflectional mirrors passing through the same point. A rank "n" Coxeter group has "n" mirrors and is represented by a Coxeter-Dynkin diagram. Coxeter notation offers a convenient way to represent these groups, with the notation [n,n] representing a rotation of 2π/n about an axis, and [n] representing a reflection across a plane.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of Bravais lattices and their relationship with point groups.

#### 1.3b Symmetry Operations

Symmetry operations are the fundamental building blocks of point groups. They are the operations that preserve the symmetry of a crystal structure. These operations can be rotations, reflections, or inversions. 

##### Rotations

Rotations are operations that move an object around a fixed axis. In the context of crystallography, rotations are operations that preserve the distance between any two points in a crystal structure. The order of a rotation is the number of times the object is rotated around the axis before returning to its original position. For example, a rotation of order 4 would rotate the object 90 degrees four times before returning to its original position.

##### Reflections

Reflections are operations that map a point to its mirror image across a plane. In crystallography, reflections are often represented by mirrors passing through the same point. The order of a reflection is always 2, as it maps a point to itself after one reflection.

##### Inversions

Inversions are operations that map a point to its inverse. An inversion is an operation that preserves the distance between any two points, but changes their orientation. Inversions are often represented by a point in the center of a sphere and a radius from that point to any other point on the sphere. The order of an inversion is always 2, as it maps a point to itself after one inversion.

##### Symmetry Operations and Point Groups

Symmetry operations are the building blocks of point groups. A point group is a set of symmetry operations that have a fixed point in common. The symmetry operations in a point group can be rotations, reflections, or inversions. The order of a point group is the number of symmetry operations in the group.

For example, the point group C<sub>4</sub>v is a group of symmetry operations that includes a rotation of order 4 and a reflection across a plane. The order of this point group is 8, as it includes 4 rotations and 4 reflections.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of Bravais lattices and their relationship with point groups.

#### 1.3c Bravais Lattice

The Bravais lattice is a concept in crystallography that describes the periodic arrangement of points in a crystal structure. It is named after the French mathematician and physicist Augustin-Louis Cauchy and the French mathematician and physicist Louis-Marie-Achille Bachelier.

##### Definition of Bravais Lattice

A Bravais lattice is a set of points in space that are equivalent under the symmetry operations of a crystal structure. In other words, a Bravais lattice is a set of points that are related to each other by symmetry operations. The points in a Bravais lattice are often referred to as lattice points or lattice sites.

The Bravais lattice is defined by the symmetry operations of the crystal structure. These symmetry operations can be rotations, reflections, or inversions, as discussed in the previous section. The symmetry operations of the Bravais lattice are represented by the point group of the crystal structure.

##### Types of Bravais Lattices

There are 230 possible types of Bravais lattices, each represented by a unique point group. These point groups are classified into seven crystal systems, which are further divided into 14 Bravais lattices.

The seven crystal systems are:

1. Cubic system: This system includes lattices with four three-fold axes. The point group for this system is $O_h$.
2. Tetragonal system: This system includes lattices with four two-fold axes. The point group for this system is $D_4h$.
3. Orthorhombic system: This system includes lattices with three two-fold axes. The point group for this system is $D_2h$.
4. Monoclinic system: This system includes lattices with two two-fold axes. The point group for this system is $C_2h$.
5. Hexagonal system: This system includes lattices with six two-fold axes. The point group for this system is $C_6h$.
6. Triclinic system: This system includes lattices with no symmetry axes. The point group for this system is $1$.
7. Isometric system: This system includes lattices with four three-fold axes and three two-fold axes. The point group for this system is $O$.

##### Bravais Lattice and Point Group

The Bravais lattice and the point group are closely related. The point group of a crystal structure determines the symmetry operations of the Bravais lattice. Conversely, the Bravais lattice of a crystal structure can be used to determine its point group.

For example, the Bravais lattice of a crystal structure with a point group of $O_h$ is a cubic system with four three-fold axes. The Bravais lattice of a crystal structure with a point group of $D_4h$ is a tetragonal system with four two-fold axes.

#### 1.3d Symmetry Operations and Point Groups

Symmetry operations and point groups are fundamental concepts in the study of crystals and their structures. They provide a mathematical framework for understanding the symmetry properties of crystals and their periodic arrangements of atoms.

##### Symmetry Operations

Symmetry operations are mathematical operations that preserve the overall shape or structure of a crystal. These operations can be rotations, reflections, or inversions, as discussed in the previous sections. They are represented by the point group of the crystal structure.

The symmetry operations of a crystal structure can be visualized as a set of symmetry operations that leave the crystal structure invariant. For example, a rotation of 90 degrees around an axis, a reflection across a plane, or an inversion through a point can all be symmetry operations of a crystal structure.

##### Point Groups

A point group is a set of symmetry operations that leave a crystal structure invariant. It is a mathematical representation of the symmetry of a crystal structure. The point group of a crystal structure is determined by the symmetry operations of the Bravais lattice of the crystal structure.

The point group of a crystal structure can be represented as a group of orthogonal matrices. Each element of the point group is a matrix that transforms the coordinates of the crystal structure. The determinant of these matrices can be either +1 or -1, depending on whether the transformation is an orientation-preserving rotation or an orientation-reversing reflection.

##### Chiral and Achiral Point Groups

Point groups can be classified into two types: chiral and achiral. A chiral point group is a point group that contains only orientation-preserving rotations, while an achiral point group contains both orientation-preserving rotations and orientation-reversing reflections.

The chiral point groups are subgroups of the special orthogonal group SO(3). They are represented by the symbol $C_{n}$, where $n$ is the order of the rotation. The achiral point groups are represented by the symbol $D_{n}$, where $n$ is the order of the rotation.

##### Symmetry Operations and Point Groups in Quasicrystals

The concept of symmetry operations and point groups is particularly important in the study of quasicrystals. Quasicrystals are aperiodic structures that exhibit long-range order, but are not periodic. They are characterized by their non-repeating patterns and their lack of translational symmetry.

The symmetry operations of quasicrystals are represented by the point group of the quasicrystal. However, unlike periodic crystals, the point group of a quasicrystal is not finite. Instead, it is an infinite cyclic group generated by a single rotation. This is due to the non-repeating nature of quasicrystals.

## Chapter: Chapter 2: The Schrödinger Equation

### Introduction

The Schrödinger Equation, named after the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger, is a fundamental equation in quantum mechanics. It describes how the quantum state of a physical system changes over time. This chapter will delve into the intricacies of the Schrödinger Equation, its implications, and its applications in the field of solid-state physics.

The Schrödinger Equation is a cornerstone of quantum mechanics, and it is used to describe the behavior of particles at the atomic and subatomic level. It is a wave equation that describes how the quantum state of a physical system changes over time. The equation is named after the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger, who first proposed it in 1926.

In the context of solid-state physics, the Schrödinger Equation is used to describe the behavior of electrons in a solid. It is a key tool in understanding the properties of materials, such as their electrical and thermal conductivity, as well as their optical and magnetic properties.

This chapter will provide a comprehensive introduction to the Schrödinger Equation, starting with its basic form and then moving on to more complex versions. We will explore how the equation is used to describe the behavior of particles in a potential field, and how it can be used to calculate the probability of finding a particle in a particular state.

We will also discuss the concept of wave-particle duality, which is central to the interpretation of the Schrödinger Equation. This concept, which states that particles can exhibit both wave-like and particle-like behavior, is a key part of quantum mechanics.

Finally, we will explore some of the applications of the Schrödinger Equation in solid-state physics, including its use in understanding the behavior of electrons in semiconductors and metals.

By the end of this chapter, you should have a solid understanding of the Schrödinger Equation and its applications in solid-state physics. #### 1.3b Symmetry Elements and Operations

In the previous section, we discussed the concept of point groups and their role in understanding the symmetries of crystals. In this section, we will delve deeper into the concept of symmetry elements and operations, which are fundamental to understanding the symmetry of a crystal structure.

##### Symmetry Elements

A symmetry element is a point, line, or plane that remains unchanged under the symmetry operations of a crystal structure. These elements are the building blocks of the symmetry of a crystal structure. They are the result of applying a symmetry operation to a point, line, or plane in the crystal structure.

For example, in a cubic crystal structure, the fourfold rotation axis is a symmetry element. This axis remains unchanged under the fourfold rotation operation. Similarly, the threefold rotation axis and the mirror plane are also symmetry elements in a cubic crystal structure.

##### Symmetry Operations

Symmetry operations are the mathematical operations that preserve the symmetry of a crystal structure. These operations include rotations, reflections, and inversions. They are represented by orthogonal matrices in the point group.

For example, in a cubic crystal structure, the fourfold rotation operation is represented by the orthogonal matrix "M" = [cos(π/4) -sin(π/4) 0; sin(π/4) cos(π/4) 0; 0 0 1]. This operation rotates the crystal structure by 90° around the fourfold rotation axis.

##### Symmetry Elements and Operations in Point Groups

In point groups, symmetry elements and operations are organized into sets of symmetry operations that leave a point, line, or plane invariant. These sets are called point, line, or plane groups, respectively.

For example, in the cubic crystal structure, the point group is the set of all symmetry operations that leave the origin of the crystal structure invariant. This point group includes the fourfold rotation operation, the threefold rotation operation, and the reflection across the mirror plane.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of Bravais lattices and their relationship with symmetry elements and operations.

#### 1.3c Symmetry Elements and Operations

In quasicrystals, the concept of symmetry elements and operations is particularly interesting due to the presence of incommensurate structures. #### 1.3c Bravais Lattice and Point Group

In the previous sections, we have discussed the concept of symmetry elements and operations, and how they are organized into point groups. In this section, we will explore the relationship between Bravais lattices and point groups, and how they are used to describe the symmetry of a crystal structure.

##### Bravais Lattice

A Bravais lattice is a periodic arrangement of points in three-dimensional space. It is the simplest form of a crystal structure, and it is used as a basis for more complex crystal structures. The Bravais lattice is defined by the Pearson symbol, which is a combination of the lattice system and the centering type.

The lattice system refers to the arrangement of lattice points in the unit cell. There are seven lattice systems: simple cubic, body-centered cubic, face-centered cubic, simple hexagonal, body-centered hexagonal, face-centered hexagonal, and cubic close-packed.

The centering type refers to the location of the lattice points in the unit cell. There are four centering types: primitive, body-centered, face-centered, and base-centered.

##### Point Group

The point group of a Bravais lattice is the set of symmetry operations that leave the lattice invariant. These operations include rotations, reflections, and inversions. The point group is represented by the symmetry operations in the point group table.

The point group table is a tabular representation of the symmetry operations of a crystal structure. It includes the symmetry operations of the point group, the symmetry elements of the crystal structure, and the symmetry operations of the unit cell.

##### Relationship between Bravais Lattice and Point Group

The relationship between the Bravais lattice and the point group is crucial in understanding the symmetry of a crystal structure. The Bravais lattice provides the geometric structure of the crystal, while the point group provides the symmetry operations that preserve this structure.

The point group of a Bravais lattice is determined by the symmetry operations of the unit cell. These operations are represented by the symmetry operations in the point group table. The point group table also includes the symmetry operations of the crystal structure, which are determined by the symmetry elements of the Bravais lattice.

In conclusion, the Bravais lattice and the point group are two fundamental concepts in the study of crystal structures. They provide a mathematical framework for understanding the symmetry of a crystal structure, and they are essential in the study of the properties of solids.

#### 1.4a Wavefunction of an Electron in a Periodic Potential

In the previous sections, we have discussed the concept of symmetry elements and operations, and how they are organized into point groups. We have also explored the relationship between Bravais lattices and point groups, and how they are used to describe the symmetry of a crystal structure. In this section, we will delve into the wavefunction of an electron in a periodic potential, which is a crucial concept in understanding the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice.

##### Bloch's Theorem

Bloch's theorem is a fundamental theorem in solid state physics that describes the behavior of electrons in a periodic potential. It states that the wavefunction of an electron in a periodic potential can be written as the product of a plane wave and a periodic function, known as the Bloch function. Mathematically, this can be represented as:

$$
\psi_k(r) = e^{ik \cdot r}u_k(r)
$$

where $k$ is the wavevector, $r$ is the position vector, and $u_k(r)$ is the Bloch function. The Bloch function is periodic over the crystal lattice, meaning that it has the same value at every point in the lattice. This is a direct consequence of the periodicity of the crystal lattice.

##### Nearly Free Electron Model

The nearly free electron model (NFE model) is an approximation used to describe the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice. It assumes that the interactions between electrons are negligible, and that the electrons behave as free particles in a periodic potential. This model is particularly useful in understanding the electronic band structure of a material.

In the NFE model, the wavefunction of an electron can be written as a linear combination of Bloch functions, each with a different wavevector. This allows us to describe the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice as a superposition of plane waves. The NFE model is particularly useful in understanding the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice, as it allows us to predict the electronic band structure of a material.

##### Consequences of Periodicity

The periodicity of the crystal lattice has significant consequences for the behavior of electrons. As mentioned earlier, the Bloch function is periodic over the crystal lattice. This means that the wavefunction of an electron in a periodic potential can be written as a linear combination of Bloch functions, each with a different wavevector. This allows us to describe the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice as a superposition of plane waves.

Furthermore, the periodicity of the crystal lattice also leads to the concept of energy bands. In the NFE model, the energy of an electron is given by the equation:

$$
E(k) = \hbar^2k^2/2m
$$

where $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck's constant, $k$ is the wavevector, and $m$ is the effective mass of the electron. This equation describes a parabolic energy band, which is a good approximation for many materials. However, for materials with a more complex crystal structure, the energy band may deviate from this parabolic form.

In conclusion, the wavefunction of an electron in a periodic potential plays a crucial role in understanding the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice. The NFE model, with its assumptions of negligible interactions and a superposition of plane waves, provides a useful framework for understanding the electronic band structure of a material. The periodicity of the crystal lattice leads to the concept of energy bands, which are crucial in understanding the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice.

#### 1.4c Bloch Theorem and Wavevector

The Bloch theorem not only provides a mathematical framework for understanding the behavior of electrons in a periodic potential, but also introduces the concept of wavevector. The wavevector, denoted as $k$, is a crucial parameter in the Bloch theorem and is directly related to the momentum of the electron.

The wavevector is defined as the derivative of the wavefunction with respect to position. Mathematically, this can be represented as:

$$
k = \frac{1}{\hbar}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\psi(r)
$$

where $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck's constant, $r$ is the position vector, and $\psi(r)$ is the wavefunction of the electron.

The wavevector is also related to the momentum of the electron through the de Broglie relation, which states that the momentum of an electron is inversely proportional to its wavevector. This can be represented as:

$$
p = \hbar k
$$

where $p$ is the momentum of the electron.

The wavevector plays a crucial role in the Bloch theorem, as it is used to index the energy bands of the material. The energy bands are regions of allowed energy levels for electrons in a material, and they are indexed by the wavevector. This allows us to understand the continuous energy levels of electrons in a crystal lattice as a superposition of plane waves, each with a different wavevector.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of energy bands in more detail, and discuss how the Bloch theorem provides a mathematical framework for understanding these bands.




#### 1.4b Bloch Theorem and Bloch Functions

In the previous section, we introduced Bloch's theorem and its significance in describing the behavior of electrons in a periodic potential. In this section, we will delve deeper into the concept of Bloch functions and their role in the Bloch theorem.

##### Bloch Functions

Bloch functions, named after the Swiss mathematician and physicist Felix Bloch, are a crucial component of Bloch's theorem. They are periodic functions that describe the behavior of electrons in a periodic potential. The Bloch function $u_k(r)$ is defined as:

$$
u_k(r) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\Omega}}e^{ik \cdot r}
$$

where $\Omega$ is the volume of the unit cell, and $k$ is the wavevector. The Bloch function is periodic over the crystal lattice, meaning that it has the same value at every point in the lattice. This is a direct consequence of the periodicity of the crystal lattice.

##### Bloch Theorem and Bloch Functions

Bloch's theorem states that the wavefunction of an electron in a periodic potential can be written as the product of a plane wave and a periodic function, known as the Bloch function. Mathematically, this can be represented as:

$$
\psi_k(r) = e^{ik \cdot r}u_k(r)
$$

where $k$ is the wavevector, $r$ is the position vector, and $u_k(r)$ is the Bloch function. The Bloch function is periodic over the crystal lattice, meaning that it has the same value at every point in the lattice. This is a direct consequence of the periodicity of the crystal lattice.

The Bloch theorem is a powerful tool in solid state physics, as it allows us to describe the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice as a superposition of plane waves. In the free electron model, the energy of an electron is given by the equation:

$$
E = \frac{\hbar^2 k^2}{2m}
$$

where $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck's constant, $k$ is the wavevector, and $m$ is the effective mass of the electron. However, in a periodic potential, the energy of an electron is not continuous, but rather discrete. This is due to the periodicity of the crystal lattice, which leads to the formation of energy bands.

##### Bloch Theorem and Energy Bands

Bloch's theorem provides a mathematical framework for understanding the formation of energy bands. According to Bloch's theorem, the wavefunction of an electron in a periodic potential can be written as the product of a plane wave and a periodic function, known as the Bloch function. This allows us to describe the behavior of electrons in a crystal lattice as a superposition of plane waves.

The energy bands of a material are formed due to the interference of these plane waves. The energy bands are separated by gaps, known as band gaps, where no electron states exist. The width of these band gaps is determined by the periodicity of the crystal lattice.

##### Nearly Free Electron Model and Energy Bands

This model is particularly useful in understanding the electronic band structure of a material.

In the NFE model, the energy bands are described by the equation:

$$
E = \frac{\hbar^2 k^2}{2m^*}
$$

where $m^*$ is the effective mass of the electron. The effective mass is a measure of how the electron's motion is influenced by the periodic potential of the crystal lattice. #### 1.4c Brillouin Zone

The Brillouin zone is a fundamental concept in solid state physics, named after the French physicist Léon Brillouin. It is a region in reciprocal space that contains all the unique k-vectors of a crystal lattice. The Brillouin zone is defined as the Wigner-Seitz cell in reciprocal space, and it plays a crucial role in the study of electronic band structure.

##### Definition of Brillouin Zone

The Brillouin zone is a polyhedron in reciprocal space that contains all the unique k-vectors of a crystal lattice. It is defined as the Wigner-Seitz cell in reciprocal space, which is the smallest volume that contains all the k-vectors of the lattice and is bounded by planes that are perpendicular to the reciprocal lattice vectors. Mathematically, the Brillouin zone can be represented as:

$$
B_k = \{k \in \mathbb{R}^3 | \langle k, G \rangle \leq 2\pi \quad \forall G \in \mathbb{G}\}
$$

where $B_k$ is the Brillouin zone, $k$ is the wavevector, $\mathbb{R}^3$ is the three-dimensional Euclidean space, $\mathbb{G}$ is the reciprocal lattice, and $\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle$ denotes the dot product.

##### Importance of Brillouin Zone

The Brillouin zone is a crucial concept in solid state physics, as it provides a convenient way to classify the k-vectors of a crystal lattice. The unique k-vectors within the Brillouin zone correspond to the unique values of the wavevector that an electron can have in a crystal lattice. This is because the Brillouin zone is the smallest volume that contains all the k-vectors of the lattice, and any k-vector outside the Brillouin zone can be reached by adding a reciprocal lattice vector to a k-vector within the Brillouin zone.

The Brillouin zone also plays a crucial role in the study of electronic band structure. The band structure of a material describes the allowed energy levels of the electrons in the material, and it is determined by the band structure equations. The band structure equations are derived from the Schrödinger equation, and they describe how the energy of an electron changes as it moves through the crystal lattice. The Brillouin zone is a key component of these equations, as it defines the range of values that the wavevector can take on.

#### 1.5a Energy Bands and Band Structure

The concept of energy bands and band structure is a fundamental aspect of solid state physics. It describes the allowed energy levels of the electrons in a solid, and it is crucial for understanding the electronic properties of materials.

##### Energy Bands

In the free electron model, the energy of an electron is given by the equation:

$$
E = \frac{p^2}{2m}
$$

where $E$ is the energy, $p$ is the momentum, and $m$ is the mass of the electron. In a solid, the energy of an electron is not continuous, but is divided into bands. These bands are regions of energy that an electron can have, and they are separated by gaps known as band gaps. The band structure of a material is determined by the band structure equations, which are derived from the Schrödinger equation.

##### Band Structure Equations

The band structure equations are a set of equations that describe the allowed energy levels of the electrons in a solid. They are derived from the Schrödinger equation, which is a fundamental equation in quantum mechanics that describes the wave-like nature of particles. The band structure equations are used to calculate the energy of the electrons in a solid, and they are crucial for understanding the electronic properties of materials.

The band structure equations are given by:

$$
\hat{H}\psi = E\psi
$$

where $\hat{H}$ is the Hamiltonian operator, $\psi$ is the wave function of the electron, and $E$ is the energy of the electron. The Hamiltonian operator is defined as:

$$
\hat{H} = -\frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\nabla^2 + V(x)
$$

where $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck's constant, $m$ is the mass of the electron, $\nabla^2$ is the Laplacian operator, and $V(x)$ is the potential energy of the electron.

##### Importance of Energy Bands and Band Structure

The concept of energy bands and band structure is crucial for understanding the electronic properties of materials. The band structure of a material determines its electrical, thermal, and optical properties. For example, the band structure of a semiconductor determines its ability to conduct electricity, while the band structure of a metal determines its reflectivity. Therefore, understanding the energy bands and band structure of a material is essential for predicting and controlling its electronic properties.

#### 1.5b Band Gaps and Brillouin Zones

The concept of band gaps and Brillouin zones is a crucial aspect of solid state physics. It is used to describe the energy levels of electrons in a solid, and it is essential for understanding the electronic properties of materials.

##### Band Gaps

Band gaps are regions in the energy spectrum where no electron states exist. They are a direct consequence of the Pauli exclusion principle, which states that no two electrons can occupy the same quantum state. In a solid, the energy levels of the electrons are grouped into bands, and the band gaps are the regions between these bands.

The size of the band gap is a key factor in determining the electronic properties of a material. For example, materials with large band gaps are insulators, as they do not allow electrons to move freely. On the other hand, materials with small band gaps are conductors, as they allow electrons to move more easily.

##### Brillouin Zones

The Brillouin zone is a region in reciprocal space that contains all the unique k-vectors of a crystal lattice. It is defined as the Wigner-Seitz cell in reciprocal space, which is the smallest volume that contains all the k-vectors of the lattice. The Brillouin zone is crucial for understanding the band structure of a material, as it is the region where the band structure equations are solved.

The concept of the Brillouin zone is closely related to the concept of the first Brillouin zone. The first Brillouin zone is the smallest volume that contains all the k-vectors of the lattice. It is defined as the region where the dot product of the k-vector and the reciprocal lattice vectors is less than or equal to 2π. Mathematically, the first Brillouin zone can be represented as:

$$
B_k = \{k \in \mathbb{R}^3 | \langle k, G \rangle \leq 2\pi \quad \forall G \in \mathbb{G}\}
$$

where $B_k$ is the Brillouin zone, $k$ is the wavevector, $\mathbb{R}^3$ is the three-dimensional Euclidean space, $\mathbb{G}$ is the reciprocal lattice, and $\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle$ denotes the dot product.

The first Brillouin zone is a polyhedron, and it is bounded by planes that are perpendicular to the reciprocal lattice vectors. The vertices of the first Brillouin zone are the points where the planes intersect. These points are known as the Brillouin zone points, and they are crucial for understanding the band structure of a material.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of the Fermi surface, which is another important aspect of solid state physics.

#### 1.5c Fermi Surface and Density of States

The Fermi surface and density of states are two fundamental concepts in solid state physics that describe the behavior of electrons in a solid. They are particularly important in the study of metals, where they play a crucial role in determining the electronic properties of the material.

##### Fermi Surface

The Fermi surface is a concept in quantum statistics that describes the distribution of fermions (particles with half-integer spin) in a system. In the context of solid state physics, the Fermi surface is a three-dimensional surface in reciprocal space that represents the energy levels of the electrons in a solid at absolute zero temperature.

The Fermi surface is defined as the set of points in reciprocal space where the energy of the electrons is equal to the Fermi energy, which is the highest occupied energy level at absolute zero temperature. Mathematically, the Fermi surface can be represented as:

$$
E_F = \frac{\hbar^2}{2m}k^2
$$

where $E_F$ is the Fermi energy, $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck's constant, $m$ is the mass of the electron, and $k$ is the wavevector.

The Fermi surface is a crucial concept in solid state physics, as it provides a visual representation of the energy levels of the electrons in a solid. It is particularly useful in the study of metals, where it is used to understand the behavior of the electrons at absolute zero temperature.

##### Density of States

The density of states (DOS) is a concept in solid state physics that describes the number of states available for electrons to occupy in a solid. It is a crucial concept in the study of metals, as it provides a quantitative measure of the number of available energy levels for the electrons in a solid.

The density of states is defined as the number of states per unit volume per unit energy. Mathematically, the density of states can be represented as:

$$
D(E) = \frac{1}{V}\frac{dN}{dE}
$$

where $D(E)$ is the density of states, $V$ is the volume of the solid, $N$ is the number of states, and $E$ is the energy.

The density of states is a crucial concept in solid state physics, as it provides a quantitative measure of the number of available energy levels for the electrons in a solid. It is particularly useful in the study of metals, where it is used to understand the behavior of the electrons at absolute zero temperature.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of the Fermi-Dirac distribution, which is another important aspect of solid state physics.

#### 1.5b Classification of Solids based on Band Structure

The band structure of a solid is a fundamental property that determines its electronic and optical properties. It is therefore crucial to understand how to classify solids based on their band structure. This classification is based on the number of energy bands and the nature of the band gap.

##### Classification of Solids

Solids can be classified into three main categories based on their band structure: metals, insulators, and semiconductors.

###### Metals

Metals are characterized by a partially filled conduction band. This means that there are available energy states for electrons to move into, which allows for the free movement of electrons. This property is responsible for the high electrical and thermal conductivity of metals. The band structure of metals can be represented as:

$$
\begin{align*}
\text{Metals:} \quad & \text{Conduction band (partially filled)} \\
& \text{Valence band (partially filled)}
\end{align*}
$$

###### Insulators

Insulators, on the other hand, have a large band gap between the valence band and the conduction band. This large gap prevents electrons from moving from the valence band to the conduction band, which results in a very low electrical conductivity. The band structure of insulators can be represented as:

$$
\begin{align*}
\text{Insulators:} \quad & \text{Conduction band (empty)} \\
& \text{Valence band (filled)}
\end{align*}
$$

###### Semiconductors

Semiconductors have a smaller band gap compared to insulators, which allows some electrons to move from the valence band to the conduction band at room temperature. This results in a moderate electrical conductivity. The band structure of semiconductors can be represented as:

$$
\begin{align*}
\text{Semiconductors:} \quad & \text{Conduction band (partially filled)} \\
& \text{Valence band (partially filled)}
\end{align*}
$$

##### Importance of Band Structure Classification

The classification of solids based on their band structure is crucial for understanding their electronic and optical properties. For example, metals are good conductors of electricity due to the partially filled conduction band, while insulators are poor conductors due to the large band gap. Similarly, the band structure of semiconductors allows for the manipulation of their electrical and optical properties, which is crucial for the design of electronic devices.




#### 1.5c Effective Mass and Density of States

The concept of effective mass is a crucial aspect of the free electron model. It is a measure of how the mass of an electron is influenced by its interactions with the lattice of atoms in a solid. The effective mass is not a constant value, but rather it can vary with the direction of motion of the electron. This is due to the anisotropic nature of the crystal lattice, which can affect the motion of the electron in different directions.

The effective mass, $m^*$, is defined as the second derivative of the energy with respect to the momentum:

$$
m^* = \frac{1}{\frac{1}{\hbar^2} \frac{d^2E}{dk^2}}
$$

where $E$ is the energy of the electron, $k$ is the wave vector, and $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck's constant. The effective mass can be positive or negative, depending on whether the energy is a convex or concave function of the momentum.

The density of states, $g(E)$, is another important concept in the free electron model. It represents the number of electron states per unit volume and per unit energy. The density of states is directly related to the probability of finding an electron at a given energy level. It is a crucial factor in determining the electrical and thermal properties of a solid.

The density of states can be calculated from the band structure of the solid. For a three-dimensional system, the density of states is given by:

$$
g(E) = \frac{1}{2\pi^2} \left(\frac{2m}{\hbar^2}\right)^{3/2} (E - E_c)^{1/2}
$$

for $E > E_c$, and $g(E) = 0$ for $E \leq E_c$, where $E_c$ is the bottom of the conduction band.

The effective mass and density of states are fundamental concepts in the study of the electronic properties of solids. They provide a deeper understanding of the behavior of electrons in a solid and their role in determining the properties of the solid.




#### 1.5d Metal, Insulator, and Semiconductor Classification

The classification of materials into metals, insulators, and semiconductors is a fundamental aspect of solid-state physics. This classification is based on the electronic properties of these materials, particularly their band structures.

Metals are characterized by a partially filled conduction band, which allows them to conduct electricity. The free electrons in the conduction band are delocalized, meaning they can move freely throughout the material. This is why metals are good conductors of electricity. The band structure of metals is typically represented by a parabolic curve, as shown in the figure below.

Insulators, on the other hand, have a fully filled valence band and an empty conduction band. This means that there are no free electrons available for conduction, making insulators poor conductors of electricity. The band structure of insulators is typically represented by a step function, as shown in the figure below.

![Band Structure of Insulators](https://i.imgur.com/6JZJZJj.png)

Semiconductors have a partially filled valence band and a partially filled conduction band. This means that there are some free electrons available for conduction, making semiconductors better conductors than insulators but not as good as metals. The band structure of semiconductors is typically represented by a linear function, as shown in the figure below.

![Band Structure of Semiconductors](https://i.imgur.com/6JZJZJj.png)

The band structure of a material can be determined experimentally using techniques such as ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). These techniques provide information about the electronic properties of a material, including the band structure.

## Chapter 2: Orthogonalized Plane Wave (OPW):

### Introduction

In the previous chapter, we introduced the concept of plane waves and their role in understanding the electronic structure of solids. We saw how plane waves can be used to describe the behavior of electrons in a periodic potential, and how they can be used to construct the band structure of a solid. However, the plane waves we used were not orthogonal to each other, which led to some complications in our calculations. In this chapter, we will introduce the concept of orthogonalized plane waves (OPWs) and see how they can simplify our calculations and provide a deeper understanding of the electronic structure of solids.

OPWs are a mathematical tool that allows us to construct a complete set of orthogonal functions that satisfy the periodic boundary conditions of a solid. These functions are constructed by orthogonalizing the plane waves with respect to the periodic potential of the solid. This process results in a set of orthogonal functions that can be used to describe the behavior of electrons in a solid.

The use of OPWs has become increasingly popular in the study of solids due to its simplicity and effectiveness in describing the electronic structure of solids. It has been applied to a wide range of systems, from simple metals to complex materials with multiple bands. In this chapter, we will explore the theory behind OPWs and see how they can be used to construct the band structure of a solid. We will also discuss some of the applications of OPWs in the study of solids.

### Subsection: 2.1a Pseudopotential Approximation

The pseudopotential approximation is a powerful tool in the study of solids, particularly in the context of the Orthogonalized Plane Wave (OPW) method. It allows us to simplify the calculations involved in constructing the band structure of a solid, while still capturing the essential physics of the system.

The pseudopotential approximation is based on the concept of a pseudopotential, which is a potential energy that is effective for the electrons in a solid, but is not the true potential energy of the ions. The pseudopotential is designed to reproduce the effects of the true potential energy on the electronic structure of the solid. This is achieved by introducing a set of pseudopotentials that are tailored to specific types of ions, such as the Phillips pseudopotential for silicon and germanium.

The pseudopotential approximation is particularly useful in the OPW method because it allows us to decouple the valence and conduction bands of a solid. This is achieved by introducing a pseudopotential that is effective only for the valence electrons, while the conduction electrons are described by a separate pseudopotential. This decoupling simplifies the calculations involved in constructing the band structure, as it allows us to focus on the valence electrons without the complications introduced by the conduction electrons.

The pseudopotential approximation has been successfully applied to a wide range of systems, from simple metals to complex materials with multiple bands. It has been particularly useful in the study of solids with a large number of atoms, such as semiconductors and insulators.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the theory behind the pseudopotential approximation and see how it can be used to construct the band structure of a solid. We will also discuss some of the applications of the pseudopotential approximation in the study of solids.

#### 2.2a Tight Binding Model

The Tight Binding (TB) model is a powerful tool in the study of solids, particularly in the context of the Orthogonalized Plane Wave (OPW) method. It is a method that combines the advantages of the Plane Wave Expansion Method and the Pseudo-spectral Method, while avoiding their disadvantages.

The TB model is based on the concept of a tight binding, which is a quantum mechanical model that describes the properties of tightly bound electrons in solids. In this model, the electrons are tightly bound to the atom to which they belong and have limited interaction with states and potentials on surrounding atoms of the solid. As a result, the wave function of the electron will be rather similar to the atomic orbital of the free atom to which it belongs. The energy of the electron will also be rather close to the ionization energy of the electron in the free atom or ion because the interaction with potentials and states on neighboring atoms is limited.

The mathematical formulation of the one-particle tight-binding Hamiltonian may look complicated at first glance, but the model is not complicated at all and can be understood in a simple way. The Hamiltonian is given by:

$$
H = \sum_{i} \epsilon_{i} c_{i}^{\dagger} c_{i} + \sum_{i,j} t_{ij} c_{i}^{\dagger} c_{j}
$$

where $c_{i}^{\dagger}$ and $c_{i}$ are the creation and annihilation operators for the electron at site $i$, $\epsilon_{i}$ is the on-site energy, and $t_{ij}$ is the hopping energy between sites $i$ and $j$. The hopping energy $t_{ij}$ is typically small compared to the on-site energy $\epsilon_{i}$, which is why the model is called the tight binding model.

The TB model is particularly useful in the OPW method because it allows us to decouple the valence and conduction bands of a solid, similar to the pseudopotential approximation. This is achieved by introducing a set of tight binding orbitals that are effective only for the valence electrons, while the conduction electrons are described by a separate set of tight binding orbitals. This decoupling simplifies the calculations involved in constructing the band structure, as it allows us to focus on the valence electrons without the complications introduced by the conduction electrons.

The TB model has been successfully applied to a wide range of systems, from simple metals to complex materials with multiple bands. It has been particularly useful in the study of solids with a large number of atoms, such as semiconductors and insulators.

#### 2.2b van Hove Singularity

The van Hove singularity is a phenomenon in the electronic band structure of solids that is particularly relevant in the context of the Tight Binding (TB) model. It is named after the Dutch physicist Leo Peter Hans van Hove, who first described this phenomenon in 1953.

The van Hove singularity occurs when the density of states (DOS) of a solid is singular at a certain energy. In the TB model, this singularity is typically associated with the Fermi level, which is the energy at which the probability of an electron being present is 50%. The singularity is a result of the band structure of the solid, and it can have significant implications for the electronic properties of the solid.

The van Hove singularity is particularly important in the context of the TB model because it can lead to a divergence in the electronic density of states. This can result in a high density of states near the Fermi level, which can significantly affect the electronic properties of the solid. For example, it can lead to a high carrier density, which can increase the conductivity of the solid.

The van Hove singularity can be understood in terms of the TB model by considering the hopping energy $t_{ij}$ between sites $i$ and $j$. If the hopping energy is large, the band structure of the solid can be significantly affected, leading to a van Hove singularity. This is because the large hopping energy can result in a high density of states near the Fermi level.

In the next section, we will discuss how the van Hove singularity can be calculated in the TB model, and how it can be used to understand the electronic properties of solids.

#### 2.2c Tight Binding and van Hove Singularity

The Tight Binding (TB) model and the van Hove singularity are closely intertwined. The TB model provides a mathematical framework for understanding the electronic band structure of solids, while the van Hove singularity is a specific phenomenon that can occur in this band structure.

In the TB model, the van Hove singularity is typically associated with the Fermi level. The Fermi level is the energy at which the probability of an electron being present is 50%. When the density of states (DOS) at the Fermi level is singular, we say that a van Hove singularity occurs.

The van Hove singularity can be calculated in the TB model by considering the derivative of the DOS with respect to energy. If the derivative is infinite at the Fermi level, a van Hove singularity occurs. This can be expressed mathematically as:

$$
\frac{dN(E)}{dE} = \frac{1}{\pi} \sum_{i} \frac{\Gamma_i}{(E - E_i)^2 + \Gamma_i^2}
$$

where $N(E)$ is the DOS, $E_i$ is the energy of the $i$-th band, and $\Gamma_i$ is the width of the $i$-th band.

The van Hove singularity can have significant implications for the electronic properties of the solid. #### 2.3a Experimental Techniques for Measuring Band Structure

The study of band structure is a fundamental aspect of solid state physics. It provides insights into the electronic properties of materials, including their electrical and thermal conductivity, optical properties, and magnetic behavior. Experimental techniques for measuring band structure have been developed to probe these properties directly.

One such technique is the photoemission spectroscopy (PES), which is used to measure the electronic band structure of materials. PES is a surface-sensitive technique that provides information about the electronic structure of the topmost layers of a material. It is based on the photoelectric effect, where the absorption of a photon by an electron in a material can cause the electron to be ejected from the material. The energy of the ejected electron is measured, which provides information about the energy levels of the electrons in the material.

The PES spectrum of a material can be represented as:

$$
I(k) = \sum_{n} A_{n} \cdot \delta(E - E_{n})
$$

where $I(k)$ is the intensity of the PES spectrum, $A_{n}$ is the amplitude of the $n$th component, $E$ is the energy of the ejected electron, and $E_{n}$ is the energy of the $n$th component. The PES spectrum provides information about the energy levels of the electrons in the material, which can be used to construct the band structure.

Another experimental technique for measuring band structure is the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), which is a surface-sensitive technique that provides information about the electronic structure of the topmost layers of a material. XPS is based on the photoelectric effect, similar to PES, but it uses X-ray photons instead of UV or visible light photons. The XPS spectrum can be represented as:

$$
I(k) = \sum_{n} A_{n} \cdot \delta(E - E_{n})
$$

where $I(k)$ is the intensity of the XPS spectrum, $A_{n}$ is the amplitude of the $n$th component, $E$ is the energy of the ejected electron, and $E_{n}$ is the energy of the $n$th component. The XPS spectrum provides information about the energy levels of the electrons in the material, which can be used to construct the band structure.

In addition to these surface-sensitive techniques, bulk-sensitive techniques such as the ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) and the infrared photoelectron spectroscopy (IPES) can also be used to measure the band structure of materials. These techniques provide information about the electronic structure of the bulk of a material, which can be complementary to the surface-sensitive techniques.

#### 2.3b Survey of the Periodic Table

The periodic table is a tabular arrangement of chemical elements, organized based on their atomic number, electron configuration, and recurring chemical properties. It is a fundamental tool in chemistry and physics, providing a visual representation of the elements and their properties. The periodic table is also a powerful tool for understanding the band structure of materials.

The periodic table can be used to predict the electronic properties of materials, including their band structure. The periodic table is organized such that elements with similar properties are grouped together. This grouping is based on the electron configuration of the atoms, which determines the electronic properties of the material.

The electron configuration of an atom is determined by the Pauli Exclusion Principle, which states that no two electrons in an atom can have the same set of quantum numbers. The quantum numbers include the principal quantum number ($n$), the azimuthal quantum number ($l$), the magnetic quantum number ($m$), and the spin quantum number ($s$). The Pauli Exclusion Principle leads to the Aufbau Principle, which states that electrons fill the lowest energy levels first, and Hund's Rule, which states that electrons will occupy empty orbitals in the same energy level before pairing up in the same orbital.

The periodic table can be used to predict the band structure of materials. The electron configuration of an atom determines the number of electrons in each energy level, and the band structure of a material is determined by the distribution of these electrons over the energy levels. The periodic table can also be used to predict the electronic properties of materials, including their electrical and thermal conductivity, optical properties, and magnetic behavior.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of the periodic table in more detail, and explore how it can be used to understand the band structure of materials.

#### 2.3c Band Structure and Electronic Properties

The band structure of a material is a fundamental concept in solid state physics. It describes the distribution of energy levels or bands that are available to electrons in a solid. The band structure is determined by the electron configuration of the atoms in the material, which is in turn determined by the Pauli Exclusion Principle and the Aufbau Principle.

The band structure of a material is directly related to its electronic properties. For example, the band structure can be used to predict the electrical and thermal conductivity of a material. The band structure can also be used to predict the optical properties of a material, including its reflectivity and transparency.

The band structure of a material can be visualized as a series of energy bands, separated by band gaps. The energy bands represent the range of energies that are available to electrons in the material. The band gaps represent the range of energies that are not available to electrons in the material.

The band structure of a material can be calculated using various computational methods, such as the density functional theory (DFT) and the ab initio methods. These methods take into account the electron configuration of the atoms in the material, as well as the interactions between the electrons and the ions in the material.

The band structure of a material can also be measured experimentally, using techniques such as the photoemission spectroscopy (PES) and the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). #### 2.3b Band Structure of Various Materials

The band structure of a material is a fundamental property that describes the allowed energy levels of electrons in the material. It is a key factor in determining the electronic properties of a material, including its electrical and thermal conductivity, optical properties, and magnetic behavior. In this section, we will explore the band structure of various materials, focusing on the band structure of semiconductors and metals.

##### Semiconductors

Semiconductors are materials that have an energy gap between the valence band (the band of electrons that are not free to move) and the conduction band (the band of electrons that are free to move). The size of this energy gap, known as the band gap, determines the electrical conductivity of the material.

The band structure of a semiconductor can be represented as:

$$
E(k) = \begin{cases}
E_{c}(k), & \text{if } E(k) > E_{gap} \\
E_{v}(k), & \text{if } E(k) \leq E_{gap}
\end{cases}
$$

where $E(k)$ is the energy of the electron as a function of its wave vector $k$, $E_{c}(k)$ is the energy of the electron in the conduction band, $E_{v}(k)$ is the energy of the electron in the valence band, and $E_{gap}$ is the band gap.

The band structure of a semiconductor can be probed experimentally using techniques such as photoemission spectroscopy (PES) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). These techniques provide information about the energy levels of the electrons in the material, which can be used to construct the band structure.

##### Metals

In contrast to semiconductors, metals have no band gap between the valence band and the conduction band. This means that all the energy levels of the electrons are continuous, and there are no energy gaps between them.

The band structure of a metal can be represented as:

$$
E(k) = E_{c}(k)
$$

where $E(k)$ is the energy of the electron as a function of its wave vector $k$, and $E_{c}(k)$ is the energy of the electron in the conduction band.

The band structure of a metal can also be probed experimentally using techniques such as PES and XPS. However, due to the continuous nature of the energy levels in metals, these techniques may provide less detailed information about the band structure compared to semiconductors.

In the next section, we will explore the band structure of various materials in more detail, focusing on the band structure of insulators and the band structure of materials with complex structures.

#### 2.3c Band Structure and Material Properties

The band structure of a material is not only a fundamental property that describes the allowed energy levels of electrons in the material, but it also plays a crucial role in determining the material's properties. In this section, we will explore the relationship between band structure and material properties, focusing on the properties of semiconductors and metals.

##### Semiconductors

The band structure of a semiconductor has a direct impact on its properties. The size of the band gap, $E_{gap}$, determines the electrical conductivity of the material. A larger band gap corresponds to a lower electrical conductivity, and vice versa. This is because the larger the band gap, the more energy is required to excite an electron from the valence band to the conduction band, and thus the fewer free electrons are available to conduct electricity.

The band structure also affects the optical properties of a semiconductor. The band gap energy, $E_{gap}$, is also the energy required to create an electron-hole pair, known as an exciton. This energy is typically in the range of photon energies, and thus semiconductors with a larger band gap are more likely to absorb and emit light. This property is exploited in many electronic devices, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs) and solar cells.

##### Metals

In metals, the continuous nature of the energy levels in the conduction band leads to high electrical conductivity. This is because there are always free electrons available to conduct electricity. However, the band structure of a metal also affects its optical properties. Metals with a high density of states at the Fermi level, such as gold and silver, are known for their high reflectivity and low absorption of light. This is due to the large number of electrons available to scatter light, and thus the high reflectivity.

In contrast, metals with a lower density of states at the Fermi level, such as copper and aluminum, are known for their high absorption of light and low reflectivity. This is because there are fewer electrons available to scatter light, and thus the lower reflectivity.
